arm_group.description: Typically developing 7- to 9-year-olds will be enrolled and tested.

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to investigate the role of the ratio of omega-6 to omega-3
      fatty acids on executive functions. The investigators hypothesize that participants ages 7-9
      years with a ratio closer to 4:1 will do better on tests of executive function than
      participants with a ratio closer to the purported Western diet norm of 15:1.

clinical_study.brief_title: Omega-6 to Omega-3 Fatty Acid Ratio and Higher Order Cognitive Function in 7-to 9-year-olds

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  typically-developing

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  not fluent in English

facility.name: UNC at Chapel Hill Nutrition Research Institute

clinical_study.official_title: Omega-6 to Omega-3 Fatty Acid Ratio and Higher Order Cognitive Function in 7-to 9-year-olds

primary_outcome.description: Executive function will be measured using a validated and standardized system known as CANTAB (Cambridge Neuropsychological Test Automated Battery) and correlated with the ratio of fatty acid intake. 24-hour diet recalls will be completed using the NDSR (Nutrient Data System for Research) software. Across one week, the children will be interviewed 3 times (two weekdays, one weekend day) about what they ate in the previous 24 hours. The dietary data will be averaged to arrive at the n-6/n-3 intake. The children will then come to lab for one visit where they will be assessed using the CANTAB.
primary_outcome.measure: Relation between executive function and n-6/n-3 fatty acid intake

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

secondary_outcome.description: Temperament will be measured using a Rothbart written assessment completed by the caregiver.
Demographic information will be collected from caregiver using a lab-typical questionnaire.

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Cross-Sectional
